BiblioData.Title: NANOROD THIN-FILM TRANSISTORS
BiblioData.Abstract: A method for forming an electronic switching device on a substrate, wherein the method comprises depositing the active semiconducting layer of the electronic switching device onto the substrate from a liquid dispersion of ligand-modified colloidal nanorods, and subsequently immersing the substrate into a growth solution to increase the diameter and/or length of the nanorods on the substrate, and wherein the as-deposited nanorods are aligned such that their long-axis is aligned preferentially in the plane of current flow in the electronic switching device.

Claims.P: CLAIMS

1. An electronic switching device having a semiconducting layer that comprises inorganic semiconducting elongate nanoparticles having a longer dimension and a shorter dimension, the average ratio of the length of the longer dimension to the length of the shorter dimension for the nanoparticles of the layer being in the range 2 to 50 and the average length of the longer dimension of the nanoparticles of the layer being less than 1000 ran, wherein the nanoparticles of the layer are generally mutually aligned.

2. An electronic switching device as claimed in claim 1, wherein the electronic switching device further comprises first and second contacts defining a current transport path through the semiconducting layer extending therebetween, the nanoparticles being generally aligned along the direction of the current transport path.

3. An electronic switching device as claimed in claim 2, wherein the distance between the first and second contacts defines a channel length and the ratio of the channel length to the average length of the longer dimension of the nanoparticles of the layer is larger than l.
4. An electronic switching device as claimed in any preceding claim, wherein the nanoparticles are uniaxially aligned within one or more domains having a diameter greater than 1000 nm.
5. An electronic switching device as claimed in any preceding claim, wherein at least some of the nanoparticles are fused together.
6. An electronic switching device as claimed in any preceding claim, wherein the nanoparticles comprise an oxide semiconductor.
7. A method as claimed in claim 6, wherein said oxide semiconductor is zinc oxide, tin oxide, zinc tin oxide, indium oxide, zinc indium oxide or indium gallium zinc oxide.
8. An electronic switching device as claimed in any preceding claim, wherein the mobility of the semiconducting layer is at least 0.5 Cm<2>V<1>S<"1>.
9. An electronic switching device as claimed in any preceding claim, wherein the density of the film is at least 50% of the bulk density of the inorganic material of which the nanoparticles comprise.

10. A method for fabricating a film of nanoparticles on a substrate, the method comprising: forming a dispersion of elongate inorganic nanoparticles in a solvent, the nanoparticles having one or more ligand molecules attached to their surface, the nanoparticles having a longer dimension and a shorter dimension, and the ligand molecules including a functional group that enhances the stability of the dispersion of the nanoparticles in the solvent; and causing the nanoparticles to be deposited onto the substrate from the dispersion by removal of the solvent at a surface of the dispersion.
11. A method as claimed in claim 10, wherein the ligands are organic or partly organic.
12. A method as claimed in claim 11, wherein said semiconducting nanoparticles comprise an oxide semiconductor.
13. A method as claimed in claim 12, wherein said oxide semiconductor is zinc oxide, tin oxide, zinc tin oxide, indium oxide, zinc indium oxide or indium gallium zinc oxide.

14. A method as claimed in any of claims 10 to 13, wherein the ligands are selected so as to cause the concentration of nanoparticles to be higher at the surface of the solution than in the bulk of the solution, and the shape of the nanoparticles is selected so as to promote mutual alignment of the nanoparticles.

15. A method as claimed in claims 10 to 14, wherein the ratio of the length of the longer dimension to the length of the shorter dimension for the nanoparticles in solution is in the range 2 to 50 and the average length of the longer dimension of the nanoparticles in solution is less than 1000 nm.
16. A method as claimed in any of claims 10 to 15, wherein the density of the film is at least 50% of the bulk density of the inorganic material of which the nanoparticles are comprised.

24. A method as claimed in any of claims 10 to 23, wherein the ligands are bound to the surface of the nanoparticles by a chelating bond.
